items.title: Trump’s $100K H-1B visa fee sparks fears #politics #shorts #trump #h1bvisa
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content: <article>From Indra Nooyi to Elon Musk to Sundar Pichai, H-1B visa holders have shaped American innovation. But a new $100,000 fee announced by the Trump administration could change that. Watch "Wall Street Week" tonight at 6 p.m. ET bloom.bg/3Jw64QH</article>

items.title: How to Make 'Perfect' Sushi With Chef Nobu
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Nobu Matsuhisa, the chef and entrepreneur behind the namesake hospitality company Nobu, teaches Bloomberg's Haslinda Amin how to make the perfect sushi and talks about one of his signature dishes, the miso black cod.
--------

items.title: Argentina After the Vote: Milei’s Mandate, Markets’ Rally, and the Pain Ahead
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Argentine President Javier Milei’s latest win strengthens his hand in pursuing economic reforms with the backing of his government. The peso enjoyed a boost and reform hopes rose, but veterans like Hans Humes warn that austerity still squeezes Argentina’s middle class and businesses. We examine what Milei’s next steps could mean for inflation, growth, and investors as the US steps in to offer its own financial support through a swap agreement. From Buenos Aires’ factory floors to global trading desks, the real test is whether momentum will hold.
--------
More on Wall Street Week

items.title: Is Europe Too Late to Compete in the Chip War?
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Bloomberg in partnership with Open to Debate hosts a debate. The U.S. and China dominate the semiconductor race — America with capital, Silicon Valley culture and trade restrictions, China with resources and talent. Europe is often seen as hampered by regulation, labor laws and limited venture capital. Yet with a near-monopoly on lithography and rising demand for tech sovereignty, Europe may be better positioned than many think. Can it catch up — or is it too late?
--------
More on Bloomberg Television and Markets

items.title: Wall Street Week | Larry Summers on the Fed, Argentina Elections, Hinton on AI, Trump’s H-1B Fee
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>This week, Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers agrees with Fed Chair Powell’s reluctance to lock in a December rate cut. And, with new congressional momentum and a victory in midterm elections, Argentina’s President Javier Milei gets the electorate’s buy-in to continue economic reforms that have had mixed results. Plus, Geoffrey Hinton, the “Godfather of AI,” warns that the race to build smarter machines is outpacing efforts to control them, and that humanity must act before it’s too late. Later, will President Trump’s $100,000 H-1B visa fee actually solve the issues of misuse and poor pay, or will it starve the US of global talent?

Chapters:
00:00:00 - Larry Summers on the Fed
00:11:54 - Milei Wins in Argentina
00:23:56 - Geoffrey Hinton on AI
00:35:51 - Trump's $100k Visa Fee
00:47:33 - Hinton on Responsible AI
--------

items.title: Larry Summers on the Fed’s Cut and a Tariff Truce with China
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Former US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers discusses the Federal Reserve’s latest rate cut and why Chair Jerome Powell’s cautious tone on a potential December cut was “exactly right.” Summers says inflation remains a bigger threat than unemployment, and warns that high deficits and global AI competition could test US leadership. He also credits President Trump with the progress made on trade with China, but warns that we are in the “early chapters” of the book.
--------
More on Wall Street Week

items.title: Nvidia CEO Outing Heats Up Korea’s Fried Chicken Stocks
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>A viral moment of Nvidia’s Jensen Huang having chimaek (fried chicken and beer) in South Korea may have made investors hungry as well.

Huang sent Korean fried chicken stocks soaring after his outing with Samsung's Jay Y Lee and Hyundai's Chung Euisun.</article>

items.title: ECB's Kocher says bar is not higher for possible December rate cut
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>"We continue to stay in a good place."
ECB governing council member Martin Kocher tells Lizzy Burden there's "no pre-commitment" on any rate path</article>

items.title: #AI is hitting the job market like a tsunami, IMF's Georgieva says
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>"This is like a tsunami hitting the labor market."
IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva tells Shery Ahn not enough attention is being given to the impact of AI adoption to jobs  bloom.bg/4odFo6d</article>

items.title: Parents Are Spending $100,000 to Chase Youth Baseball Glory
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Youth baseball isn’t just a pastime anymore – it’s an industry. And for families chasing big-league dreams, the price tags can be staggering. Max Rivera explains why many parents say the chance for a scholarship or a shot at the pros are well worth it.
--------

items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Stonex Groups’ Kathryn Rooney Vera, GoDaddy’s Aman Bhutani, TD Cowen’s Jason Gabelman, Aon’s Greg Case, Crossmark Global Investments’ Victoria Fernandez, Rithm’s Michael Nierenberg, Wellington’s Laura Kirk, Rithm Capital CEO, Speedrun’s Andrew Chen and Sweatpals’ Salar Shahini, Mr Chow’s Michael Chow, Catch Hospitality Group’s Eugene Remm.

items.title: Federal Ruling Orders Trump to Use Emergency SNAP Funding, But Will He?
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Gina Plata-Nino, SNAP Director at the Food Research & Action Center, discusses the future of SNAP benefits as funding is set to run out by November 1. She also talks about the federal judges ruling that orders President Trump to use emergency snap funding, data showing that most SNAP participants are located in Trump-won districts, and how individual states are handling SNAP benefits on their own. Gina Plata-Nino speaks with Joe Mathieu on the late edition of Bloomberg's "Balance of Power."
--------

items.title: Three Key Races to Watch Ahead of Election Day 2025
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Cook Political Report US House Editor Erin Covey previews the races to watch on Election Day including the NYC Mayoral race where Covey suggests Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani is likely to win as polling shows he has a double digit lead over Independent candidate Andrew Cuomo. She also discusses both the Virginia & New Jersey gubernatorial races and how the ongoing government shutdown may motivate who people will vote for. Erin speaks with Joe Mathieu on the late edition of Bloomberg's "Balance of Power."
--------

items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content:
<article>Bloomberg's Mishal Husain breaks down her interview with Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado, who told her that she supports US military escalation in her country and says Maduro's time is over.

items.title: Summers happy Trump-Xi summit didn't "spiral out of control" #shorts #trump #xijinping #politics
items.author: Bloomberg Television
items.content: <article>Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers says he's happy the meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping didn't "spiral out of control into massive confrontation and economic conflict." Watch "Wall Street Week" Friday at 6 p.m. ET https://bloom.bg/3X4QheI</article>
